name: IMRC
mission: IMRC has been working for over four decades to support Muslims and minorities in India. We fund education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief.
theoryOfChange: IMRC states it supports Muslims and minorities in India by funding year-round projects in education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief through 100+ partners on the ground, aiming to create real, measurable change.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat (Source: https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 34/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Separate restricted/endowment funds from operating reserves and publish a clear reserve-use policy.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities shows strong impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat (Source: https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: IMRC reported total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8%.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and follows specific zakat policies and asnaf categories.
IMRC's mission is to help India's Muslims and minorities achieve security, freedom, equality, and rights.
The organization provides meals, water access, and medical treatment to beneficiaries.
IMRC supports students and provides meals as part of its core programming.
Program outcomes include thousands of patients treated and students supported.
IMRC manages Ramadan and Qurbani distribution alongside healthcare treatments.
The charity has a history of building wells and distributing meals to marginalized communities.
IMRC offers various donation options including Zakat and general giving methods.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: IMRC earns a solid overall rating due to its high financial efficiency and direct service model, though its score is tempered by medium data confidence and the inherent challenges of advocacy work.
areas_for_improvement: Enhance data confidence by providing more recent third-party impact evaluations.
Increase transparency regarding specific long-term advocacy outcomes for minority rights.

dimension_explanations.alignment: IMRC shows high alignment for Muslim donors as a Zakat-eligible organization that follows specific asnaf categories for distribution [2][9]. Its long track record of serving vulnerable populations in India addresses urgent humanitarian and advocacy needs [8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high direct impact through its healthcare and education programs, treating thousands of patients and supporting students across India [6][7]. With a total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8%, IMRC maintains strong financial health to support its mission [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities empowers India’s marginalized minorities through robust education, healthcare, and emergency relief programs.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.8%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach beneficiaries.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.01 to raise every $1.
Strong liquidity with 55.7 months of working capital available.
baseline_narrative.summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) works to help India's Muslims and minorities achieve security, freedom, and equality as citizens [1][3]. The organization operates comprehensive programs in education and healthcare while maintaining a high level of financial efficiency [4][5].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: IMRC earns a solid overall rating due to its high financial efficiency and direct service model, though its score is tempered by medium data confidence and the inherent challenges of advocacy work.

areas_for_improvement.detail: The organization has seen a <cite id="9">3-year revenue CAGR of -10.2%</cite>, suggesting a need to diversify or revitalize its donor base.
While IMRC reports high-level outputs, it lacks <cite id="17">third-party impact evaluations</cite> to verify long-term outcomes for its beneficiaries.

bbb_assessment.summary: Data on BBB standards compliance is currently unavailable.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's massive <cite id="10">$48.7 million asset base</cite> mitigates short-term financial risks.
risk_factors: <cite id="9">Negative 10.2% revenue growth</cite> over three years
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="9">declining revenue trends</cite> and a lack of <cite id="17">rigorous external impact data</cite>.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data from 2023, impact reports through 2021
confidence.notes: Strong historical data but recent revenue declines and lack of external evaluation impact the score.

alignment.explanation: IMRC is a premier fit for Muslim donors, offering <cite id="20">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serving the <cite id="21">fuqara (poor) and masakin (needy)</cite> in India.
alignment.improvement: The organization could improve alignment by <cite id="22">expanding services to more underserved geographies</cite> within India that have limited nonprofit coverage.

credibility.explanation: IMRC is a highly established entity with <cite id="1">over four decades of history</cite> and a <cite id="16">fully independent board</cite>. It maintains <cite id="18">$48.7 million in total assets</cite>, providing a massive safety net for its operations.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should <cite id="17">seek external evaluations</cite> and publish audited financial statements more prominently.

impact.explanation: The charity demonstrates high efficiency with <cite id="6">$0.01 fundraising costs</cite> and a <cite id="12">program ratio reaching 89.8%</cite> in some reporting periods. It provided <cite id="15">16.4 million meals</cite> in a single year.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="19">publishing consistent beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for cost-per-beneficiary analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Output tracking via annual reports

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service delivery through its own infrastructure

rich_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities empowers India’s marginalized minorities through robust education, healthcare, and emergency relief programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the long-term resilience of Indian Muslim communities through an established, high-efficiency institution.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat obligations for the most vulnerable in India
Value low overhead and high fundraising efficiency
Prefer supporting established organizations with 40+ years of history
Care about holistic support including education and healthcare
giving_considerations: The organization is currently experiencing a revenue contraction
Impact is reported in outputs (meals, students) rather than long-term outcomes
Large asset reserves mean the charity is highly stable but may have less immediate funding urgency
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-growth startups or those requiring rigorous academic impact evaluations (RCTs).

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects consistent output tracking (e.g., <cite id="7">16,493 students supported</cite>) without external validation.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IMRC uses a multi-sectoral approach (education, health, water) to alleviate poverty and empower minorities in India.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Consistent tracking ensures that the <cite id="15">millions of meals provided</cite> actually reach the intended populations.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While assets are high, the <cite id="9">declining revenue trend</cite> suggests a need for new capital to maintain program scale.

peer_comparison.differentiator: IMRC stands out for its <cite id="6">unusually low fundraising costs</cite> compared to its peer group median.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses on social justice in the US South
similar_organizations.name: Project South

strengths.detail: The organization spends only <cite id="6">$0.01 to raise every $1</cite>, a metric far superior to industry averages.
IMRC maintains a <cite id="11">program expense ratio of 89.8%</cite> according to recent filings, while historical data shows ratios as high as <cite id="12">89.8%</cite>.
With over <cite id="1">40 years of experience</cite> since its founding in 1981, IMRC has built a massive infrastructure for <cite id="13">direct service delivery</cite> in India.

strengths_deep_dive: IMRC’s operational strength lies in its ability to scale basic services to millions. Their healthcare initiatives treated <cite id="8">183,100 patients in 2021</cite> and <cite id="14">102,314 patients in 2019</cite>, demonstrating consistent delivery capacity. Furthermore, their feeding programs reached a peak during the pandemic, providing over <cite id="15">16.4 million meals in 2020</cite>. This scale is supported by a <cite id="16">100% independent board</cite> of 14 members, ensuring strong oversight and governance standards.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">1981</cite>, Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) is a veteran humanitarian organization dedicated to supporting India’s marginalized Muslim and minority communities. The organization operates with a mission to help these populations achieve <cite id="2">security, freedom, equality, and their rights as citizens</cite>. IMRC manages a diverse portfolio of interventions, including <cite id="3">education, healthcare, clean water, and emergency relief</cite> across various Indian states, including Jammu and Kashmir. In 2023, the organization reported <cite id="4">total revenue of $13,833,809</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="5">$13.39 million in public contributions</cite>. IMRC is noted for its lean operational model, maintaining a <cite id="6">fundraising efficiency of $0.01 per $1 raised</cite>, which ensures that donor funds are directed almost entirely toward program delivery rather than administrative overhead. Their impact is substantial; for instance, in 2021 alone, the charity supported <cite id="7">16,493 students</cite> and provided medical treatment to <cite id="8">183,100 patients</cite>. Despite a <cite id="9">3-year revenue CAGR of -10.2%</cite>, the organization remains financially stable with <cite id="10">$48.7 million in net assets</cite> and significant liquidity to sustain its long-term commitments to underserved regions.
